newsitem.title: CANADA: Hollinger looking at shifting some assets.
newsitem.headline: Hollinger looking at shifting some assets.

text.p: A report due out next week will help determine whether Conrad Black's Hollinger Inc will sell its Canadian newspapers to unit Hollinger International Inc, Hollinger Inc president and chief operating officer David Radler said on Friday.

An independent committee of the board of Hollinger International has hired brokerage RBC Dominion Securities to put a value on Hollinger Inc's Canadian newspaper assets -- including the Sterling and Armadale newspaper groups -- and will report next week on whether it thinks a deal is in the interests of shareholders.
"The purpose is to get everything under one roof. Now that Southam Inc is under (the Hollinger International) roof, then everything should go under that roof," Radler said in a telephone interview.
"We may get some knowledge of that from the report next week. But we may also determine that it will go no further," he added.

Hollinger International on Thursday concluded its bid for enough Southam shares to bump its stake to a majority. It wanted more than 50 percent of Canada's largest-circulation newspaper group so it could consolidate Southam's results.
A total of 22.43 million Southam shares were deposited under the sweetened C$20 per share offer and Hollinger plans to take up and pay for eight million of these on a pro rata basis by December 8.
Originally, Hollinger offered C$18.75 until a committee of independent Southam directors pushed for a higher offer.
-- Sarah Edmonds, Reuters Toronto Bureau (416) 941-8100, E-mail sarah.edmonds@reuters.com
